title: Can I learn Korean without liking K-Pop music? - Quora

response.answer_text: The better question here should be, 'Do you actually 'LIKE' Korean?' The thing about language is, no matter how dedicated you choose to be at the start, if you don't give yourself a passionate reason why you're learning the language, you're sure to get bored and make a switch. The Korean language, much like any other language, is learnt with simple steps of words, to phrases, to sentences. From this point, you know you're already speaking the language.,but what keeps you going through this phase, is the vision you have in your head that expresses the passion you have for the language. You've decided to minor in Korean, but you feel hesitant to proceed. Why? Because there's a small part of you that tells you, that you'll be inconsistent along the way. That you might not be able to give enough to get the most out of the language. You don't need KPOP to learn Korean. It's a language. But for efficient learning, and familiarity with the phonetics of the language, it's recommended to listen to KPOP. It's kinda like mnemonics that help to improve cognitive ability, and improve your capacity to retain and recall info. It's fun, it helps you get used to the language, and the have talented artists that entertain you whilst you learn. Talk about learning with a fun experience! You might not like KPOP. The sight of white feminine boys in shorts might disgust you. Heck, you might not even like Korean, but If you do choose to learn Korean, it will be like learning any other language along with all the rigorous learning concepts that will further stress you, IF you don't learn without KPOP (or K-Dramas) Try KPOP today, and you'll see the effects it'll have on you.

Most definitely, you can. I learn Japanese without liking and watching/listening to Japanese music or anime (le gasp!) And I’m doing well. In fact, a lot of people in my class who love anime and J-Pop have really bad grades in the class and struggle a lot despite it all. It really depends more on the effort you put into learning, not just absorbing in pop culture. I even draw in manga style without liking the above. I would suggest you try to watch Korean movies or dramas though if you can help it because hearing the language is reallllly helpful to learning (when I USED to like anime back in middle school I learned so much Japanese that I forgot now even though I’m taking the class). Music however? Nah. That’s okay. It’s a little hard to learn proper grammar, inflection, etc when just listening to the music… You’ll be fine. Just be prepared to be in a class with a lot of K-Pop lovers… or to have people assume that you love K-Pop because you’re taking Korean. I have both these problems in Japanese class… people don’t believe me when I say I’ve only ever seen about 6 short anime series in my life, and the last one I watched was about 3 years ago…

According to my personal experience, while listening to Korean music, you just enjoy the exciting rhythm instead of focusing on language itself. This theory can be applied in many foreign language songs including Chinese, Japanese and other oriental language. Listening to Korean songs or watching films and variety shows can be a recreational assistant way to learn Korean instead of main methods, especially for the language beginner. Honestly speaking, there is no direct connection between listening to loads of songs and studying one foreign language well. On the one hand, lyrics are not common words that can be used in daily life. It would be weird to answer questions using lyrics from songs. On the other hand, some songs mixed Korean English and native slang which are difficult for beginner to understand their meanings. Therefore, while listening to Korean music, you just enjoy the exciting rhythm instead of focusing on vocabulary and syntax. Korean as an oriental language is different from western languages. In the last century, Korean government gradually abolished the use of Chinese character in daily life as well as most official documents, and written Korean has evolved to an alphabetic language. It is much easier for you to know the pronunciation of each word, but it is difficult to know their exact meanings which only can be understood by the whole sentence. If you decided to minor in Korean, the fundamental stuff is to master the most basic pronunciation, grammar and syntax rather than listen to music as a main approach. By the way, after having completed basic language courses, you can watch some variety shows to improve your sensitivity and proficiency to Korean, which is more useful and efficient compared with listening to music. There are many benefits of watching well-elaborated Korean variety shows. You can be familiar with the history, custom, current fashion and behavior style of Korean that can help you understand language better. The glamour of some Korean host can break the cultural divergence and shock your heart. I believe programmes hosted by Yu Jae Seok will not make you disappointed. I am curious about now that you are not interested in K-pop, what your reasons are for studying Korean. After all, most people around me study Korean for enjoying the pleasure K-pop brings to them better. -

Sure thing! There’s so many fascinating values from korea aside from it’s pop culture which one you usually refer with k-pop. You can start with the easiest way, from your very tummy! Korean cuisine is varies from the most popular kimchi, bibimbab to various jjigae (stew), ttang (soup) to kkochi (skrewer). As for me, i learn korean through dramas, movies, and variety shows. And they came in various genres! You like romance, there’s sweet stories of two ridicullously attractive people fell in love with each other in architectures 101, or when you like thrill and crime stories more than romance you can watch signal for drama and crime scere for variety. And my list can go on. P.s. not a native, please do correct my mistakes in grammar and such when you spot it, thank you

I learnt Korean for 7 years (have a Bachelors and a Masters degree in Korean) and have been teaching Korean at a university for last 2 years. I also passed the highest level of Korean proficiency test (TOPIK). And I don't like K-POP. I never did. I am also not a fan of Korean drama. I like some Korean movies but for their great stories and not because they are Korean movies. I hated Korean food until 5 years back. Now I have developed the taste and just love it. :) But I like Korea, its culture and language and that's enough motivation to learn Korean. But sometimes people also learn the languages of the countries they really hate, because their job requires them to do so or sometimes because they love the language linguistically and so on. So nothing should stop you from learning Korean if you want to. All the best!

That’s like asking if you can learn English without liking Beyonce’s music. Of COURSE you can learn a language without liking the corresponding country’s popular music. If you are going to be taking Korean language lessons at your university, they will (hopefully) be teaching you how to say basic key phrases you would need, like “Hello,” “Where is the subway?” and “How much is this?” K-pop has a lot of words and phrases that you will hear peppered throughout a lot of K-pop songs, but it’s kind of hard to learn the most important stuff just from listening to music. Also, there are other genres of Korean music out there besides pop. You can also watch Korean TV shows, like K-dramas and variety shows. Those might be more useful considering you can see the facial expressions and gestures that go along with what is being said, which may help you learn new phrases easier.

Of course you can; although k-pop gets really popular, you dont have to like it to learn the language. There are alot more different ways you can appreciate the language and its culture, though there were no doubt some who chose to learn the language because of k-pop; just like some who wanted to learn japanese due to anime. There are other types of music as well, its not as if all koreans listen to only pop. If music isnt your thing, so be it. Even if you are just learning the language because they look prettier in writing its also a valid reason.

Of course you can. I guess it'll be the same as learning English. Many also say listening to pop-song is one of good ways of learning it. However, I've been studying it without having pressure about that. I haven't even thought like it would be better if I were a person who likes pop song. Maybe I would watch movies or dramas more because those are what I like. I don't actually quite get the idea that people "should" learn Korean through K-pop. Its grammar and spellings are not even often correct, and I don't think most of the lyrics are healthy.

Yes you can learn Korean without liking k-pop. If you want to practice your listening skills in Korean besides listening to k-pop, you can always watch Korean children shows or Korean shows in general. While I listen to k-pop, I also watch children shows because is a great way to pick up basic vocabulary. Good luck learning Korean!

Yes you can definitely learn Korean without liking the K-pop music. Music is a great way to channel your interests, however, it is not mandatory for everyone. If you are interested in watching some Korean Movies or Korean Dramas, along with a good support from a Korean E-Learning program, you will be able to keep your interest in. Hope this helped.

Well Everyone have their own method on how to learn, and by coincidence Kpop music is one of the popular alternative for people to learn Korean. ‘Cause they want to learn because of it. So You can learn Korean without liking K-pop music, No harm done. Try to learn it your own way, maybe on Watching K-drama, Korean Variety Shows (Running Man, 2D1N ) Just for preference on knowing new words to add on your vocab and Listening Skill And Of course have a lot of will of wanting to learn Korean Language (but to note, learning a language also learning a little bit about the culture :D )

There are many forms of Korean music besides K-pop, just like with American music. Keep looking for the kind you want, I’m sure you can find something, unless you don’t like it because of the sound of the language. Watching Korean movies and tv shows is also a good way to get to know the sound of the language. There are apps you can download, and meet korean people to speak with. K-pop is not the only way

Of course you can learn Korean without liking Kpop. Honestly, sometimes I find it better without the music. Some idols tend to pronounce words differently in order for them to flow well with the song. There are plenty of other sources online like books, videos, Korean shows, etc. You don't have to learn Korean with the music alone.

I think a lot of people learn Korean due in some part to K-Pop. That aside, can you learn French without listening to French pop music, of course you can! There’s one site I recommend for Korean, they have an abundant amount of free lessons and and videos. The site is Learning Korean made simple Talk To Me In Korean is a great free resource (they also have published books and workbooks if you want to go that route) and I have yet to see a K-Pop reference.

Obviously you can. For example, to learn Hindi you can learn it many ways not that you can only learn ny watching hindi music videos right. You can surf or watch videos to learn any language not only Korean. If you watch Korean dramas and k-pop too you can learn Korean but it is not only the way. Try learning from watching Korean language tutorials.

As many have said before me, ‘of course you can’. There is certainly more to Korea than K-pop or K-drama. Korea as a nation is a diverse, rich and innovative culture with a unique and exotic take on life as oppose to a typical western lifestyle. If you are learning Korean language as a complete beginner, as a resource, you could always try out flashcard/quiz vocabulary builders like beginnerkorean app or StartFromZero_Korean app. Alternatively, once you are more adept in the language you could use more advanced Hangul learning tools such as TOPIK Locker app to practice your vocabulary.

Of course. It would just help you have to have more materials to learn from, but you can certainly choose other options if you don’t like Kpop like Korean dramas or webtoons or variety shows or games, probably. Just try it. It’s fun learning another language. :)

Of course . You don’t need to like Kpop in order to learn Korean . You can maybe see their news channel , or pick some subjects that you like . Travel ? if you like travel , then there are some shows that specifically talks about travelling in South Korea .

Yes of course you can! I live in Korea, and I am surrounded by kpop music everywhere I go. It was never my taste, but I kinda grew immune to it. Besides, your hating kpop probably won’t affect your Korean language learning, so you’ll be fine.

Yes, of course. It’s more like testing how much Korean you know when you listen to it. Kpop isn’t the only and not the best way to learn Korean. The best would be talking with a teacher or a Korean friend (who knows native level Korean).

Yes, of course! Just like with any other language. It is easier if you talk to natives or just listen to Korean daily. For some that means K-pop, for you that can be whatever entertains you! Have fun time learning Korean!

of course you can. Korea is full of other medias if you’re looking forward to learn a language through the media. Korean soap operas are fun to watch, and there are a lot of comedy shows which thoroughly explains how Koreans act.
Of course you can! Technically Korean babies learned the language without even knowing what Kpop or Kdramas were, they probably didn’t even know what Korea was!
I think that if you listen and try to understand Korean through many activities it might help, so probably listening to K-POP might help a little to the study with enjoyment?
Absolutely! I'm learning Korean by watching the same soap operas again and again and again!
yes you can
